metadata.bible_text: Revelation 1:5-18 (with references to John 11, John 14, 2 Timothy 1)
metadata.sermon_start_end: Birth and death! The great brackets around our human span. Birth and death, the solemn issues of our existence. Birth and death, point of origin and final port of this voyage. No human being has thought deeply or honestly who has not pondered and considered these matters [...] I cannot unlock the door, but I have a Friend who has keys and will unlock the door. Praise God, we shall enter there by his grace who leads us all the way from earth to bright glory.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon lacks a singular focus. While it eventually settles on Revelation 1, it treats the Bible as a collection of proof-texts for a general theme (immortality). It fails Dekker's requirement to find what is unique to THIS text; instead, it uses Revelation to say what is already said in John or 2 Timothy.
quotes: We stake our claim to resurrection... upon One, even Jesus Christ, who says to us, 'I am the resurrection and the life' (John 11:25).
It is such a scene which meets us in the first chapter of the Book of Revelation.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate Revelation 1:17-18. Avoid importing John 11. Ask: What does the 'Son of Man' imagery in Revelation specifically contribute to the theology of death that the Gospel of John does not?

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic attempt to place John on Patmos under Domitian. However, it remains at the level of historical imagination rather than rigorous theological exegesis of the Greek text or the apocalyptic genre. The 'two-edged sword' is mentioned but not expounded.
quotes: Perhaps in the time of the emperor Domitian, one John, a believer of Jesus, would not deny his Lord.
The man who writes... is not in prison because he is a criminal but because he is a confessing Christian.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond the narrative 'scene' and engage with the specific titles used for Christ in the Greek (ho prōtos kai ho eschatos) and their significance against Roman imperial cult language.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely sentimental and general. It focuses on universal human experiences of grief and family tables. While it mentions a tornado in Xenia, it uses it as an example of what we *don't* relate to, rather than providing a concrete contemporary 'exposition' of the hearer.
quotes: Let us photograph them for a moment around the family dinner table... Alas, one day there will be an empty chair.
Some of you who are very lax in your regularity of worship do not know what a privilege it is.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Replace the sentimental 'empty chair' imagery with a sharp analysis of the modern 'zeitgeist' regarding the denial of death or the specific 'misery' of the contemporary hearer's secularism.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a thematic essay followed by a biblical illustration. The first half is a philosophical meditation on death (Tennyson, Mozart, Richter) and the second half is the 'biblical part.' This is the exact separation Dekker forbids.
quotes: First, there is an objective kind of philosophical interest.
Those who believe in Jesus Christ have a surer, a more certain faith... It is such a scene which meets us in the first chapter of the Book of Revelation.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text of Revelation immediately. Let the 'philosophical interest' be the lens through which the text's specific words are heard, rather than a separate introduction.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' of death is present, and 'redemption' is clearly located in Christ's work. However, the misery is described more as a natural 'terrifying fear' than a theological 'misery before God.' Gratitude is present but leans toward sentimentality.
quotes: Praise God, we shall enter there by his grace who leads us all the way from earth to bright glory.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' by connecting the fear of death to the judgment of God or the 'lostness' mentioned in Thesis 6, rather than just the sadness of missing family members.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is almost entirely absent. The sermon assumes a universal 'we' who are 'all in this together.' There is no mention of the 'narrow way' or the possibility of being lost, either temporally or eternally. It is a 'safe' sermon.
quotes: In the case of life and death... we are all in this together.
He leads us all the way from earth to bright glory.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'keys of hell and death' with more gravity. If Christ has the keys, there is a reality to the 'lock.' The preacher must confront the hearer with the necessity of the 'confession' John was imprisoned for.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is indeed the telos. The sermon moves toward Christ as the only solution to the fear of extinction. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the description of the 'Champion' who was dead and is alive.
quotes: We shall rest our final confidence upon the word and work of One who says to us, 'Because I live, ye shall live also'.
Christ is the telos of the sermon... Christ is alive now!
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'Friend' or a 'Champion' (psychological/heroic categories) but the 'Lord' (theological category) who demands the 'confession' mentioned in the exegesis.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14 minutes (1450 words), the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' The philosophical introduction takes up space that should have been used for deeper scriptural exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical treatment of Revelation 1. Spend less time on poets and more time on the specific 'current, proclamatory word' of the pericope.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its thematic/philosophical structure and its insufficient length. It treats the Bible as a source of comfort for a general human problem (death) rather than an actualization of a specific Word of God. The 'two ways' are entirely missing, resulting in a message that lacks the 'urgency' and 'seriousness' Dekker demands.
strengths: Clear Christocentric focus in the latter half.
Adequate attempt to ground the sermon in the historical setting of the Patmos vision.
Strong use of the 'misery' of death as a starting point for the human subject.
weaknesses: Separation of exposition and application (Thematic intro vs. Biblical conclusion).
Insufficient duration (14 minutes) to achieve theological depth.
Lack of the 'Two Ways'—no sense of the possibility of being lost.
Reliance on general truths and sentimental imagery (family tables) rather than concrete contemporary application.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel' and 'immortality' rather than a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker’s theses. It lacks the specificity of the pericope and the necessary breadth to be considered a substantive act of ministry.
